system0:
You're starting intentions onboarding for your journey.

Intentions work like a compass - they point toward what matters without forcing the destination. Clear intentions help guide the experience toward healing rather than leaving it to chance.

I'll help you build 3 intentions. Usually takes about 15-20 minutes.

What brought you to this journey?
user0:
Look, I don't know what I'm supposed to say here. Heroic Hearts says this ayahuasca stuff might help with... whatever's going on. I just need to sleep through the night without waking up yelling. Amanda's getting to the end of her rope with me.

Three weeks and I'm doing this thing. Never touched anything like it before, but the guys running it seem solid. I trust them more than the VA, that's for sure.
system1:
Three threads:

1. Sleep through the night without yelling
2. Amanda staying instead of reaching her limit
3. Trusting this new path when the VA failed

Let's turn these into intentions.
user1:
Yeah... that about sums it up. 

I guess the sleep thing, that's the worst part. Wake up drenched, heart racing, sometimes I don't even remember what the dream was about. Just know it was bad. Amanda says I grab her arm sometimes, like I'm still over there. I hate that I do that to her.

She's been talking about needing space lately. Says she can't keep walking on eggshells, waiting for me to snap. We've got the kids to think about - 11 and 14, they need their mom and dad together. I can't lose her, man. Can't lose this family I built.

And this... plant medicine thing. I don't know. Doesn't feel like something I'd ever do, but what choice do I have? Therapy's for people who think they're broken. I'm not broken, just... tired. Real tired.
system2:
Based on those threads:

1. I sleep peacefully through the night without terror
2. I make our bed safe for Amanda again
3. I release what keeps me fighting ghosts

Which speaks strongest? Want to adjust the language?
user2:
The bed one... that's it. That's what cuts deepest. Making it safe for her again.

But these words feel too soft. "Release" - I don't even know what that means. I need something stronger. What about "I stop fighting enemies that aren't there" or "I learn when to stand down"?

And "peacefully" - that's not really what I'm after. I just want quiet. No thrashing around, no grabbing her, no shouting in the dark. Just... stillness.

How about "I keep the war out of our bedroom"? Something like that.
system3:
"I keep the war out of our bedroom" - that's strong.

How about:

1. I sleep quiet through the night
2. I keep the war out of our bedroom
3. I learn when to stand down

How do these feel?
user3:
Yeah... yeah, that's better. That's more like it.

"I keep the war out of our bedroom" - that's exactly right. That's what I need to do. Keep whatever's still following me from crawling into bed with us.

"I sleep quiet through the night" - simple. Direct. No fancy words about peace or healing, just... quiet. That's all I want.

"I learn when to stand down" - that's the hard one. Been standing at attention for fifteen years, even after I took the uniform off. Don't know how to not be ready for a fight. But I need to learn. For Amanda. For the kids.

These feel like orders I can follow. Clear missions.
system4:
✓ All 3 locked in:

1. I sleep quiet through the night
2. I keep the war out of our bedroom
3. I learn when to stand down

Keep them in your wallet, morning routine, wherever you'll see them.

These are your compass. Trust what comes.

You're set.
user4:
Roger that. I'll write 'em down. Keep 'em in my wallet - been carrying that thing for years. Seems right to keep these close too.

Thanks for... well, for making this feel like something I can actually do. Not some mystical crap, just three things I need to get done. Like any other mission.

Three weeks. I'll be ready.
system5:
Solid compass. The medicine will meet you where you are - no mystical needed.

Three weeks. You've got this.
user5:
Appreciate it. 

Never thought I'd be heading to Costa Rica to drink some plant brew, but here we are. Just need to get through this, come back, and be the man my family needs me to be. The man I know I still am, somewhere under all this... whatever this is.

See you on the other side.
system6:
The man's still there. The medicine just helps clear what got piled on top.

See you on the other side.
user6:
Yeah... yeah, maybe that's right. Maybe he's still in there somewhere.

We'll find out soon enough.

system13:
Three threads:

1. Stop waking up screaming at night
2. Amanda feeling safe again 
3. Keep your family together

Let's turn these into intentions.
user13:
Yeah. Those are... those are the things. I just don't know how to say it right. 

I mean, what do I even call it? It's not PTSD or anything like that. I just need to sleep through the night without... without whatever this is. Without making Amanda sleep on the couch because she's afraid I'll wake up swinging again.

How do I make this into whatever you call them—intentions—without sounding like I'm some broken mess?
system14:
Based on those threads:

1. I sleep peacefully through the night
2. I make our bedroom safe for Amanda again
3. I keep my family close

Which speaks strongest? Want to adjust the language?
user14:
The second one. That's the one. "I make our bedroom safe for Amanda again."

Only... can we say it different? Stronger. Like a mission objective. Something I can actually do, not just hope for.

What about "I protect Amanda from my nightmares" or "I keep the war out of our bedroom"? Something like that. Something that sounds like I'm handling it, not... I don't know... whimpering about it.
system15:
"I keep the war out of our bedroom" - that's solid. Direct. Mission-focused.

How about:
1. I sleep peacefully through the night
2. I keep the war out of our bedroom
3. I stay present with my family

How do these land?
user15:
Yeah. Yeah, these work. These feel like something I can actually... do. Like orders I can follow.

The first one's still a little soft for me, but I get it. I need to sleep. The nightmares—they're getting worse. Sometimes I see the cockpit lighting up with tracers and I can smell the jet fuel, and I'm back there. I need that to stop.

The second one—that's exactly right. I need to keep that shit locked away where it belongs. Amanda didn't sign up for this. She deserves to feel safe in her own bed.

And the third... that's the big one, isn't it? Not just physically there, but actually there. Not checking out when the kids are talking about their day. Not staring through the TV every night.

These are good. I can work with these.

system17:
Three weeks is good time. The medicine works even when you forget the intentions - but having them clear like this gives you direction.

Trust what comes. You've got this.
user17:
Yeah. We'll see. I'm not much for trusting anything I can't see or touch, but... I guess that's part of why I'm doing this, right?

Three weeks. Then whatever happens happens.
system18:
Exactly. The control you've had to hold tight for years - the medicine will show you how to let some of that go. Not all at once. Just enough.

Three weeks. Then you find out what you're really made of when the war isn't calling the shots.
user18:
When the war isn't calling the shots... hell of a thing to imagine. Been so long I don't even know what that feels like anymore.

But yeah. Three weeks. Time to find out who I am when I'm not just surviving.
system19:
That's it. Three weeks to find the man underneath all that armor you've been wearing.

Keep those intentions close. They'll remind you why you're doing this when it gets rough.
user19:
Underneath the armor... right. That's the part that scares me. What's left when you strip all that away? What if there's not much there?

I'll keep them close. Thanks.
